segment.source: 4738(S) A user account was changed.
segment.target: 4738(S) A user account was changed.

segment.source: (Windows 10)
segment.target: (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes security event 4738(S) A user account was changed.
segment.target: Describes security event 4738(S) A user account was changed.

segment.source: 4738(S): A user account was changed.
segment.target: 4738(S): A user account was changed.

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016
segment.target: Windows Server 2016

segment.source: Event Description:
segment.target: Event Description:

segment.source: This event generates every time user object is changed.
segment.target: This event generates every time user object is changed.

segment.source: This event generates on domain controllers, member servers, and workstations.
segment.target: This event generates on domain controllers, member servers, and workstations.

segment.source: For each change, a separate 4738 event will be generated.
segment.target: For each change, a separate 4738 event will be generated.

segment.source: You might see this event without any changes inside, that is, where all Changed Attributes apear as “-“.
segment.target: You might see this event without any changes inside, that is, where all Changed Attributes apear as “-“.

segment.source: This usually happens when a change is made to an attribute that is not listed in the event.
segment.target: This usually happens when a change is made to an attribute that is not listed in the event.

segment.source: In this case there is no way to determine which attribute was changed.
segment.target: In this case there is no way to determine which attribute was changed.

segment.source: For example, if the discretionary access control list (DACL) is changed, a 4738 event will generate, but all attributes will be “-“.
segment.target: For example, if the discretionary access control list (DACL) is changed, a 4738 event will generate, but all attributes will be “-“.

segment.source: Some changes do not invoke a 4738 event.
segment.target: Some changes do not invoke a 4738 event.

segment.source: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.
segment.target: Note For recommendations, see Security Monitoring Recommendations for this event.

segment.source: Event XML:
segment.target: Event XML:

segment.source: Required Server Roles: None.
segment.target: Required Server Roles: None.

segment.source: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.
segment.target: Minimum OS Version: Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista.

segment.source: Event Versions: 0.
segment.target: Event Versions: 0.

segment.source: Field Descriptions:
segment.target: Field Descriptions:

segment.source: Subject:
segment.target: Subject:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “change user account” operation.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that requested the “change user account” operation.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).
segment.target: Note A security identifier (SID) is a unique value of variable length used to identify a trustee (security principal).

segment.source: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.
segment.target: Each account has a unique SID that is issued by an authority, such as an Active Directory domain controller, and stored in a security database.

segment.source: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.
segment.target: Each time a user logs on, the system retrieves the SID for that user from the database and places it in the access token for that user.

segment.source: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.
segment.target: The system uses the SID in the access token to identify the user in all subsequent interactions with Windows security.

segment.source: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.
segment.target: When a SID has been used as the unique identifier for a user or group, it cannot ever be used again to identify another user or group.

segment.source: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.
segment.target: For more information about SIDs, see Security identifiers.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “change user account” operation.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that requested the “change user account” operation.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: subject’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.
segment.target: For some well-known security principals, such as LOCAL SERVICE or ANONYMOUS LOGON, the value of this field is “NT AUTHORITY”.

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”
segment.target: Logon ID Type = HexInt64: hexadecimal value that can help you correlate this event with recent events that might contain the same Logon ID, for example, “4624: An account was successfully logged on.”

segment.source: Target Account:
segment.target: Target Account:

segment.source: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that was changed.
segment.target: Security ID Type = SID: SID of account that was changed.

segment.source: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.
segment.target: Event Viewer automatically tries to resolve SIDs and show the account name.

segment.source: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.
segment.target: If the SID cannot be resolved, you will see the source data in the event.

segment.source: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that was changed.
segment.target: Account Name Type = UnicodeString: the name of the account that was changed.

segment.source: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: target account’s domain or computer name.
segment.target: Account Domain Type = UnicodeString: target account’s domain or computer name.

segment.source: Formats vary, and include the following:
segment.target: Formats vary, and include the following:

segment.source: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO
segment.target: Domain NETBIOS name example: CONTOSO

segment.source: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local
segment.target: Lowercase full domain name: contoso.local

segment.source: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL
segment.target: Uppercase full domain name: CONTOSO.LOCAL

segment.source: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.
segment.target: For local user accounts, this field will contain the name of the computer or device that this account belongs to, for example: “Win81”.

segment.source: Changed Attributes:
segment.target: Changed Attributes:

segment.source: If attribute was not changed it will have “–“ value.
segment.target: If attribute was not changed it will have “–“ value.

segment.source: Unfortunately, for local accounts, all fields, except changed attributes, will have previous values populated.
segment.target: Unfortunately, for local accounts, all fields, except changed attributes, will have previous values populated.

segment.source: Also, the User Account Control field will have values only if it was modified.
segment.target: Also, the User Account Control field will have values only if it was modified.

segment.source: Changed attributes will have new values, but it is hard to understand which attribute was really changed.
segment.target: Changed attributes will have new values, but it is hard to understand which attribute was really changed.

segment.source: SAM Account Name Type = UnicodeString: logon name for account used to support clients and servers from previous versions of Windows (pre-Windows 2000 logon name).
segment.target: SAM Account Name Type = UnicodeString: logon name for account used to support clients and servers from previous versions of Windows (pre-Windows 2000 logon name).

segment.source: If the value of sAMAccountName attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of sAMAccountName attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For example: ladmin.
segment.target: For example: ladmin.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.

segment.source: Display Name Type = UnicodeString: it is a name, displayed in the address book for a particular account.
segment.target: Display Name Type = UnicodeString: it is a name, displayed in the address book for a particular account.

segment.source: This is usually the combination of the user's first name, middle initial, and last name.
segment.target: This is usually the combination of the user's first name, middle initial, and last name.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: If the value of displayName attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of displayName attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.

segment.source: User Principal Name Type = UnicodeString: internet-style login name for the account, based on the Internet standard RFC 822.
segment.target: User Principal Name Type = UnicodeString: internet-style login name for the account, based on the Internet standard RFC 822.

segment.source: By convention this should map to the account's email name.
segment.target: By convention this should map to the account's email name.

segment.source: If the value of userPrincipalName attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of userPrincipalName attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field is not applicable and always has “-“ value.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field is not applicable and always has “-“ value.

segment.source: Home Directory Type = UnicodeString: user's home directory.
segment.target: Home Directory Type = UnicodeString: user's home directory.

segment.source: If homeDrive attribute is set and specifies a drive letter, homeDirectory should be a UNC path.
segment.target: If homeDrive attribute is set and specifies a drive letter, homeDirectory should be a UNC path.

segment.source: The path must be a network UNC of the form ServerShareDirectory.
segment.target: The path must be a network UNC of the form ServerShareDirectory.

segment.source: If the value of homeDirectory attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of homeDirectory attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.

segment.source: Home Drive Type = UnicodeString: specifies the drive letter to which to map the UNC path specified by homeDirectory account’s attribute.
segment.target: Home Drive Type = UnicodeString: specifies the drive letter to which to map the UNC path specified by homeDirectory account’s attribute.

segment.source: The drive letter must be specified in the form “DRIVELETTER:”.
segment.target: The drive letter must be specified in the form “DRIVELETTER:”.

segment.source: For example – “H:”.
segment.target: For example – “H:”.

segment.source: If the value of homeDrive attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of homeDrive attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.

segment.source: Script Path Type = UnicodeString: specifies the path of the account’s logon script.
segment.target: Script Path Type = UnicodeString: specifies the path of the account’s logon script.

segment.source: If the value of scriptPath attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of scriptPath attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.

segment.source: Profile Path Type = UnicodeString: specifies a path to the account's profile.
segment.target: Profile Path Type = UnicodeString: specifies a path to the account's profile.

segment.source: This value can be a null string, a local absolute path, or a UNC path.
segment.target: This value can be a null string, a local absolute path, or a UNC path.

segment.source: If the value of profilePath attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of profilePath attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.

segment.source: User Workstations Type = UnicodeString: contains the list of NetBIOS or DNS names of the computers from which the user can logon.
segment.target: User Workstations Type = UnicodeString: contains the list of NetBIOS or DNS names of the computers from which the user can logon.

segment.source: Each computer name is separated by a comma.
segment.target: Each computer name is separated by a comma.

segment.source: The name of a computer is the sAMAccountName property of a computer object.
segment.target: The name of a computer is the sAMAccountName property of a computer object.

segment.source: If the value of userWorkstations attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of userWorkstations attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field is not applicable and always appears as “value not set.“
segment.target: For local accounts, this field is not applicable and always appears as “value not set.“

segment.source: Password Last Set Type = UnicodeString: last time the account’s password was modified.
segment.target: Password Last Set Type = UnicodeString: last time the account’s password was modified.

segment.source: If the value of pwdLastSet attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of pwdLastSet attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: This value will be changed, for example, after manual user account password reset.
segment.target: This value will be changed, for example, after manual user account password reset.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.

segment.source: Account Expires Type = UnicodeString: the date when the account expires.
segment.target: Account Expires Type = UnicodeString: the date when the account expires.

segment.source: If the value of accountExpires attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of accountExpires attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field always has some value—if the account's attribute was not changed it will contain the current value of the attribute.

segment.source: Primary Group ID Type = UnicodeString: Relative Identifier (RID) of user’s object primary group.
segment.target: Primary Group ID Type = UnicodeString: Relative Identifier (RID) of user’s object primary group.

segment.source:
Note
Relative identifier (RID) is a variable length number that is assigned to objects at creation and becomes part of the object's Security Identifier (SID) that uniquely identifies an account or group within a domain.
segment.target:
Note
Relative identifier (RID) is a variable length number that is assigned to objects at creation and becomes part of the object's Security Identifier (SID) that uniquely identifies an account or group within a domain.

segment.source: This field will contain some value if user’s object primary group was changed.
segment.target: This field will contain some value if user’s object primary group was changed.

segment.source: You can change user’s primary group using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in the Member Of tab of user object properties.
segment.target: You can change user’s primary group using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in the Member Of tab of user object properties.

segment.source: You will see a RID of new primary group as a field value.
segment.target: You will see a RID of new primary group as a field value.

segment.source: For example, RID 513 (Domain Users) is a default primary group for users.
segment.target: For example, RID 513 (Domain Users) is a default primary group for users.

segment.source: Typical Primary Group values for user accounts:
segment.target: Typical Primary Group values for user accounts:

segment.source: 513 (Domain Users.
segment.target: 513 (Domain Users.

segment.source: For local accounts this RID means Users) – for domain and local users.
segment.target: For local accounts this RID means Users) – for domain and local users.

segment.source: See this article https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/243330 for more information.
segment.target: See this article https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/kb/243330 for more information.

segment.source: If the value of primaryGroupID attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of primaryGroupID attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: AllowedToDelegateTo Type = UnicodeString: the list of SPNs to which this account can present delegated credentials.
segment.target: AllowedToDelegateTo Type = UnicodeString: the list of SPNs to which this account can present delegated credentials.

segment.source: Can be changed using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Delegation tab of user account, if at least one SPN is registered for user account.
segment.target: Can be changed using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Delegation tab of user account, if at least one SPN is registered for user account.

segment.source: If the SPNs list on Delegation tab of a user account was changed, you will see the new SPNs list in AllowedToDelegateTo field (note that you will see the new list instead of changes) of this event.
segment.target: If the SPNs list on Delegation tab of a user account was changed, you will see the new SPNs list in AllowedToDelegateTo field (note that you will see the new list instead of changes) of this event.

segment.source: This is an example of AllowedToDelegateTo:
segment.target: This is an example of AllowedToDelegateTo:

segment.source: dcom/WIN2012
segment.target: dcom/WIN2012

segment.source: dcom/WIN2012.contoso.local
segment.target: dcom/WIN2012.contoso.local

segment.source: If the value of msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of msDS-AllowedToDelegateTo attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: The value can be “value not set”, for example, if delegation was disabled.
segment.target: The value can be “value not set”, for example, if delegation was disabled.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field is not applicable and always has “-“ value.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field is not applicable and always has “-“ value.

segment.source:
Note
Service Principal Name (SPN) is the name by which a client uniquely identifies an instance of a service.
segment.target:
Note
Service Principal Name (SPN) is the name by which a client uniquely identifies an instance of a service.

segment.source: If you install multiple instances of a service on computers throughout a forest, each instance must have its own SPN.
segment.target: If you install multiple instances of a service on computers throughout a forest, each instance must have its own SPN.

segment.source: A given service instance can have multiple SPNs if there are multiple names that clients might use for authentication.
segment.target: A given service instance can have multiple SPNs if there are multiple names that clients might use for authentication.

segment.source: For example, an SPN always includes the name of the host computer on which the service instance is running, so a service instance might register an SPN for each name or alias of its host.
segment.target: For example, an SPN always includes the name of the host computer on which the service instance is running, so a service instance might register an SPN for each name or alias of its host.

segment.source: Old UAC Value Type = UnicodeString: specifies flags that control password, lockout, disable/enable, script, and other behavior for the user account.
segment.target: Old UAC Value Type = UnicodeString: specifies flags that control password, lockout, disable/enable, script, and other behavior for the user account.

segment.source: This parameter contains the previous value of userAccountControl attribute of user object.
segment.target: This parameter contains the previous value of userAccountControl attribute of user object.

segment.source: New UAC Value Type = UnicodeString: specifies flags that control password, lockout, disable/enable, script, and other behavior for the user account.
segment.target: New UAC Value Type = UnicodeString: specifies flags that control password, lockout, disable/enable, script, and other behavior for the user account.

segment.source: If the value of userAccountControl attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of userAccountControl attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: To decode this value, you can go through the property value definitions in the “Table 7.
segment.target: To decode this value, you can go through the property value definitions in the “Table 7.

segment.source: User’s or Computer’s account UAC flags.”
segment.target: User’s or Computer’s account UAC flags.”

segment.source: from largest to smallest.
segment.target: from largest to smallest.

segment.source: Compare each property value to the flags value in the event.
segment.target: Compare each property value to the flags value in the event.

segment.source: If the flags value in the event is greater than or equal to the property value, then the property is "set" and applies to that event.
segment.target: If the flags value in the event is greater than or equal to the property value, then the property is "set" and applies to that event.

segment.source: Subtract the property value from the flags value in the event and note that the flag applies and then go on to the next flag.
segment.target: Subtract the property value from the flags value in the event and note that the flag applies and then go on to the next flag.

segment.source: Here's an example: Flags value from event: 0x15
segment.target: Here's an example: Flags value from event: 0x15

segment.source: Decoding:
segment.target: Decoding:

segment.source: • PASSWDNOTREQD 0x0020
segment.target: • PASSWDNOTREQD 0x0020

segment.source: • LOCKOUT 0x0010
segment.target: • LOCKOUT 0x0010

segment.source: • HOMEDIRREQUIRED 0x0008
segment.target: • HOMEDIRREQUIRED 0x0008

segment.source: • (undeclared) 0x0004
segment.target: • (undeclared) 0x0004

segment.source: • ACCOUNTDISABLE 0x0002
segment.target: • ACCOUNTDISABLE 0x0002

segment.source: • SCRIPT 0x0001
segment.target: • SCRIPT 0x0001

segment.source: 0x0020 0x15, so PASSWDNOTREQD does not apply to this event
segment.target: 0x0020 0x15, so PASSWDNOTREQD does not apply to this event

segment.source: 0x10 0x15, so LOCKOUT applies to this event.
segment.target: 0x10 0x15, so LOCKOUT applies to this event.

segment.source: 0x4 0x5, so the undeclared value is set.
segment.target: 0x4 0x5, so the undeclared value is set.

segment.source: We'll pretend it doesn't mean anything.
segment.target: We'll pretend it doesn't mean anything.

segment.source: 0x2 0x1, so ACCOUNTDISABLE does not apply to this event
segment.target: 0x2 0x1, so ACCOUNTDISABLE does not apply to this event

segment.source: 0x1 = 0x1, so SCRIPT applies to this event.
segment.target: 0x1 = 0x1, so SCRIPT applies to this event.

segment.source: 0x1 - 0x1 = 0x0, we're done.
segment.target: 0x1 - 0x1 = 0x0, we're done.

segment.source: So this UAC flags value decodes to: LOCKOUT and SCRIPT
segment.target: So this UAC flags value decodes to: LOCKOUT and SCRIPT

segment.source: User Account Control Type = UnicodeString: shows the list of changes in userAccountControl attribute.
segment.target: User Account Control Type = UnicodeString: shows the list of changes in userAccountControl attribute.

segment.source: You will see a line of text for each change.
segment.target: You will see a line of text for each change.

segment.source: See possible values in here: “Table 7.
segment.target: See possible values in here: “Table 7.

segment.source: User’s or Computer’s account UAC flags.”.
segment.target: User’s or Computer’s account UAC flags.”.

segment.source: In the “User Account Control field text” column, you can see the text that will be displayed in the User Account Control field in 4738 event.
segment.target: In the “User Account Control field text” column, you can see the text that will be displayed in the User Account Control field in 4738 event.

segment.source: User Parameters Type = UnicodeString: if you change any setting using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Dial-in tab of user’s account properties, then you will see value changed, but not displayed in this field.
segment.target: User Parameters Type = UnicodeString: if you change any setting using Active Directory Users and Computers management console in Dial-in tab of user’s account properties, then you will see value changed, but not displayed in this field.

segment.source: For local accounts, this field is not applicable and always has “value not set“ value.
segment.target: For local accounts, this field is not applicable and always has “value not set“ value.

segment.source: SID History Type = UnicodeString: contains previous SIDs used for the object if the object was moved from another domain.
segment.target: SID History Type = UnicodeString: contains previous SIDs used for the object if the object was moved from another domain.

segment.source: Whenever an object is moved from one domain to another, a new SID is created and becomes the objectSID.
segment.target: Whenever an object is moved from one domain to another, a new SID is created and becomes the objectSID.

segment.source: The previous SID is added to the sIDHistory property.
segment.target: The previous SID is added to the sIDHistory property.

segment.source: If the value of sIDHistory attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of sIDHistory attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: Logon Hours Type = UnicodeString: hours that the account is allowed to logon to the domain.
segment.target: Logon Hours Type = UnicodeString: hours that the account is allowed to logon to the domain.

segment.source: If the value of logonHours attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.
segment.target: If the value of logonHours attribute of user object was changed, you will see the new value here.

segment.source: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.
segment.target: You can change this attribute by using Active Directory Users and Computers, or through a script, for example.

segment.source: Here is an example of this field:
segment.target: Here is an example of this field:

segment.source: Sunday 12:00 AM - 7:00 PM
segment.target: Sunday 12:00 AM - 7:00 PM

segment.source: Sunday 9:00 PM -Monday 1:00 PM
segment.target: Sunday 9:00 PM -Monday 1:00 PM

segment.source: Monday 2:00 PM -Tuesday 6:00 PM
segment.target: Monday 2:00 PM -Tuesday 6:00 PM

segment.source: Tuesday 8:00 PM -Wednesday 10:00 AM
segment.target: Tuesday 8:00 PM -Wednesday 10:00 AM

segment.source: For local accounts this field is not applicable and typically has value “All”.
segment.target: For local accounts this field is not applicable and typically has value “All”.

segment.source: Additional Information:
segment.target: Additional Information:

segment.source: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were used during the operation, for example, SeBackupPrivilege.
segment.target: Privileges Type = UnicodeString: the list of user privileges which were used during the operation, for example, SeBackupPrivilege.

segment.source: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “-”.
segment.target: This parameter might not be captured in the event, and in that case appears as “-”.

segment.source: See full list of user privileges in “Table 8.
segment.target: See full list of user privileges in “Table 8.

segment.source: User Privileges.”.
segment.target: User Privileges.”.

segment.source: Security Monitoring Recommendations
segment.target: Security Monitoring Recommendations

segment.source: For 4738(S): A user account was changed.
segment.target: For 4738(S): A user account was changed.

segment.source: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.
segment.target: Important For this event, also see Appendix A: Security monitoring recommendations for many audit events.

segment.source: Some organizations monitor every 4738 event.
segment.target: Some organizations monitor every 4738 event.

segment.source: If you have critical user computer accounts (for example, domain administrator accounts or service accounts) for which you need to monitor each change, monitor this event with the “Target AccountAccount Name” that corresponds to the critical account or accounts.
segment.target: If you have critical user computer accounts (for example, domain administrator accounts or service accounts) for which you need to monitor each change, monitor this event with the “Target AccountAccount Name” that corresponds to the critical account or accounts.

segment.source: If you have user accounts for which any change in the services list on the Delegation tab should be monitored, monitor this event when AllowedToDelegateTo is not -.
segment.target: If you have user accounts for which any change in the services list on the Delegation tab should be monitored, monitor this event when AllowedToDelegateTo is not -.

segment.source: This value means the services list was changed.
segment.target: This value means the services list was changed.

segment.source: Consider whether to track the following fields:
segment.target: Consider whether to track the following fields:

segment.source: Field to track
segment.target: Field to track

segment.source: Reason to track
segment.target: Reason to track

segment.source: Display Name
segment.target: Display Name

segment.target: User Principal Name

segment.source: Home Directory
segment.target: Home Directory

segment.target: Home Drive

segment.target: Script Path

segment.target: Profile Path

segment.target: User Workstations

segment.target: Password Last Set

segment.source: Account Expires
segment.target: Account Expires

segment.source: Primary Group IDLogon Hours
segment.target: Primary Group IDLogon Hours

segment.source: We recommend monitoring all changes for these fields for critical domain and local accounts.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring all changes for these fields for critical domain and local accounts.

segment.source: Primary Group ID is not 513
segment.target: Primary Group ID is not 513

segment.source: Typically, the Primary Group value is 513 for domain and local users.
segment.target: Typically, the Primary Group value is 513 for domain and local users.

segment.source: Other values should be monitored.
segment.target: Other values should be monitored.

segment.source: For user accounts for which the services list (on the Delegation tab) should not be empty: AllowedToDelegateTo is marked value not set
segment.target: For user accounts for which the services list (on the Delegation tab) should not be empty: AllowedToDelegateTo is marked value not set

segment.source: If AllowedToDelegateTo is marked value not set on user accounts that previously had a services list (on the Delegation tab), it means the list was cleared.
segment.target: If AllowedToDelegateTo is marked value not set on user accounts that previously had a services list (on the Delegation tab), it means the list was cleared.

segment.source: SID History is not -
segment.target: SID History is not -

segment.source: This field will always be set to - unless the account was migrated from another domain.
segment.target: This field will always be set to - unless the account was migrated from another domain.

segment.source: Consider whether to track the following user account control flags:
segment.target: Consider whether to track the following user account control flags:

segment.source: User account control flag to track
segment.target: User account control flag to track

segment.source: Information about the flag
segment.target: Information about the flag

segment.source: 'Normal Account' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Normal Account' – Disabled

segment.source: Should not be disabled for user accounts.
segment.target: Should not be disabled for user accounts.

segment.source: 'Password Not Required' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Password Not Required' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not typically be enabled for user accounts because it weakens security for the account.
segment.target: Should not typically be enabled for user accounts because it weakens security for the account.

segment.source: 'Encrypted Text Password Allowed' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Encrypted Text Password Allowed' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not typically be enabled for user accounts because it weakens security for the account.
segment.target: Should not typically be enabled for user accounts because it weakens security for the account.

segment.source: 'Server Trust Account' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Server Trust Account' – Enabled

segment.source: Should never be enabled for user accounts.
segment.target: Should never be enabled for user accounts.

segment.source: Applies only to domain controller (computer) accounts.
segment.target: Applies only to domain controller (computer) accounts.

segment.source: 'Don't Expire Password' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Don't Expire Password' – Enabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for critical accounts, or all accounts if your organization does not allow this flag.
segment.target: Should be monitored for critical accounts, or all accounts if your organization does not allow this flag.

segment.source: 'Smartcard Required' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Smartcard Required' – Enabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for critical accounts.
segment.target: Should be monitored for critical accounts.

segment.source: 'Password Not Required' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Password Not Required' – Disabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”
segment.target: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”

segment.source: 'Encrypted Text Password Allowed' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Encrypted Text Password Allowed' – Disabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”
segment.target: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”

segment.source: 'Don't Expire Password' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Don't Expire Password' – Disabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”
segment.target: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”

segment.source: 'Smartcard Required' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Smartcard Required' – Disabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”
segment.target: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”

segment.source: 'Trusted For Delegation' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Trusted For Delegation' – Enabled

segment.source: Means that Kerberos Constraint or Unconstraint delegation was enabled for the user account.
segment.target: Means that Kerberos Constraint or Unconstraint delegation was enabled for the user account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: 'Trusted For Delegation' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Trusted For Delegation' – Disabled

segment.source: Means that Kerberos Constraint or Unconstraint delegation was disabled for the user account.
segment.target: Means that Kerberos Constraint or Unconstraint delegation was disabled for the user account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: Also, if you have a list of user accounts for which delegation is critical and should not be disabled, monitor this for those accounts.
segment.target: Also, if you have a list of user accounts for which delegation is critical and should not be disabled, monitor this for those accounts.

segment.source: 'Trusted To Authenticate For Delegation' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Trusted To Authenticate For Delegation' – Enabled

segment.source: Means that Protocol Transition delegation was enabled for the user account.
segment.target: Means that Protocol Transition delegation was enabled for the user account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: 'Trusted To Authenticate For Delegation' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Trusted To Authenticate For Delegation' – Disabled

segment.source: Means that Protocol Transition delegation was disabled for the user account.
segment.target: Means that Protocol Transition delegation was disabled for the user account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: Also, if you have a list of user accounts for which delegation is critical and should not be disabled, monitor this for those accounts.
segment.target: Also, if you have a list of user accounts for which delegation is critical and should not be disabled, monitor this for those accounts.

segment.source: 'Not Delegated' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Not Delegated' – Enabled

segment.source: Means that Account is sensitive and cannot be delegated was checked for the user account.
segment.target: Means that Account is sensitive and cannot be delegated was checked for the user account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: 'Not Delegated' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Not Delegated' – Disabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”
segment.target: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”

segment.source: Means that Account is sensitive and cannot be delegated was unchecked for the user account.
segment.target: Means that Account is sensitive and cannot be delegated was unchecked for the user account.

segment.source: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.
segment.target: We recommend monitoring this to discover whether it is an approved action (done by an administrator), a mistake, or a malicious action.

segment.source: 'Use DES Key Only' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Use DES Key Only' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not typically be enabled for user accounts because it weakens security for the account’s Kerberos authentication.
segment.target: Should not typically be enabled for user accounts because it weakens security for the account’s Kerberos authentication.

segment.source: 'Don't Require Preauth' – Enabled
segment.target: 'Don't Require Preauth' – Enabled

segment.source: Should not be enabled for user accounts because it weakens security for the account’s Kerberos authentication.
segment.target: Should not be enabled for user accounts because it weakens security for the account’s Kerberos authentication.

segment.source: 'Use DES Key Only' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Use DES Key Only' – Disabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”
segment.target: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”

segment.source: 'Don't Require Preauth' – Disabled
segment.target: 'Don't Require Preauth' – Disabled

segment.source: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”
segment.target: Should be monitored for all accounts where the setting should be “Enabled.”
